content.body: Hixie, <foreignObject> is kind of too broken to hand author stuff today
tons of crap is broken with it, so not much content exists using it, so UAs aren't motivated to fix i
t
what's broken?
I'm going to run with roc's statement that it seems fine to just elide <foreignObject> for HTML elements.
most of the things that are broken in <foreignObject> are just UA bugs
well they're certainly not going to go away if we make it more subtle :-)
oh jeez, a sudden influx of i18n bugs
roc, agree re: they are UA bugs. the rest of my statement still applies in that case
I think Gecko's foreignObject support is pretty good
our main limitation is that we don't have accelerated compositing for the contents of <foreignObject> yet but we're working toward it

'I am sorry that an overt adherence to "process" blinds some people to positive gains made when people come together and talk to each other, rather than assuming nothing but malevolent actions' coming from John Foliot, that's an instant classic

annevk: of gmail? or of annevk.nl?

oh i don't e-mail from gmail
ah, I guess I need to setup some kind of SMTP account?

on annevk.nl
so you can just point your mx records at gmail and so on
I'd rather not have another Google account
Hixie: anyway, if hixie.ch is just an alias, how do you send email from there?
pine doesn't care where you say you send mail from, it just happily puts the from address on there
and the dreamhost smtp servers are fine with it because they know it's one of my dreamhost addresses, i presume
annevk: which mail client do you use?
i occasionally e-mail from gmail, and gmail seems fine with it too, didn't have to do anything special there
annevk: i think you normally setup a separate account with gmail's credential for username/password
Hixie: oh, I had to authenticate it there
Hixie: are you sure you're not importing a DreamHost POP3 account into Gmail?
there is no dreamhost pop3 account to forward
so yes
rniwa: I haven't really decided yet which email client to use; I'm using Opera at the moment; not sure how good it is at handling multiple accounts
ian⊙hc is just a forwarding alias
there's no inbox behind it
annevk: http://support.google.com/mail/bin/answer.py?hl=en&answer=22370
same as *@spam.hixie.ch
finally found a manual on this :D
hates page redesigns that moves URLs around :(
annevk: honestly, the best mail client for gmail is gmail itself. i've tried several mail clients that try to support gmail features
annevk: but none of them support labels well.
annevk: it's fine as long as you have only one label at a time
but as soon as you start adding 2-3 labels, it gets all confused :(
rniwa: ah k
annevk: i highly recommend "preview pane" in labs
maybe Gmail is efficient enough
annevk: yeah, i think the only reason you want to use mail clients to see emails offline
i suppose you would do that much more often than i do as a spec. author though...
rniwa: does preview pane require a minimum width?
annevk: you can do vertical split as well.
Hixie: I guess the problem is that I don't have a DreamHost SMTP setup as far as I know
annevk: (it defaults to horizontal split)
mail.annevk.nl
is your smtp server
i believe
oh i guess if you don't have an account at dreamhost for your mail you wouldn't have an account on it though
right :)
can you create a bogus account?
annevk: setup a local SMTP server :D
rniwa: I meant that it doesn't split now when enabled
oh :)
Hixie: yeah I could do that
annevk: oh that's weird :\
or find a better email client that allows you to configure the From address
annevk: maybe it doesn't work on Opera :\
because per the page from rniwa Gmail is fine with it
rniwa: ah could be
on his iphone? :-P
as if apple would allow that :-P
annevk: fwiw, i used to run smtp server locally to send my emails.
not sure if that's practical anymore though given all the sender id nonsense
rniwa: same problem in Safari
annevk: odd
annevk: did you select "horizontal split"?
annevk: next to < > buttons on the upper right corner
there is a button with 3 lines
if you click the downward arrow mark there, you can select "no split", "horizontal split", and "vertical split"
annevk: maybe it's "no split" by default. although that'll be extremely silly

oh

anyway, I can now email from my iPhone as annevk⊙an and I don't have a custom/DreamHost SMTP setup yet

sp.ec/html ?

.ec requires 3 characters I think
Yeah
it's also expensive

can we use just html5.org/html etc?

oh selectors is under css

but I'm not sure it's really worth it

so html5.org is an archaic domain name

jgraham, so
There's two things I'd like to do
and I have an emailed exchange with the previous owner about the price

The other is telling a test "I've given up on you, if you get any more results, don't tell me about them, because I don't care"

Ms2ger: I think my solution does that
Depending on what you mean by "test"
So in your testharnessreport.js you would set explicit_timeout to true
That would be line timeout:infinity
*like
Then when you want to give up on a test you would call timeout()
That would set the status of any tests without results to "Not Run", and cause the page to try and report its results in the normal way
and prevent anything further happening

TabAtkins, I am wondering if you can list http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/www-style/2012Apr/0152 in the list of CSS3 V&U issue list. I have a patch for Gecko pending working group resolution on this → https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=751805

I noticed that in your Syntax draft, url() can't be escaped, but I guess David wants a working group resolution.

oh
So the question is whether it is possible to create a parser-inserted script after load fires

In HTML5 spec, is several dt's after another supposed to OR-ed or AND-ed?
Ms2ger: Only in my mind
it's a relationship between <dt> and <dd>, so OR
but maybe we should document that somehow
annevk: OK, like I thought.
Ms2ger: But it would simply be exposing the internal Tests.prototype.timeout

annevk: Yes, I tried finding it in http://dev.w3.org/html5/spec/introduction.html#structure-of-this-specification

with Boilerplate Conformance, Terminology, etc.
and then other specs just say "See boilerplate"
plus changes

annevk: or make Anolis insert the boilerplate

didn't know

wow

heh
kennyluck: Sorry, mirc wasn't binging me for mentions.
MikeSmith: ah yeah
TabAtkins, nah, no problem.
I intend to resolve that so that it's completely impossible.
In other words, so that url() doesn't allow it (because it's all parsed as a URL), and \url() is an unknown function.
image() will allow attr(), because it takes a <string> type value (not STRING tokens, like url()).
TabAtkins, I am in favor of that for what it's worth. The whole question is whether \url() can be considered a <url>.
is \u the same as u?
because then yes
I think WebKit as well as the formal grammar in CSS2.1 disallow this. Gecko allows this, so is a test case in the CSS2.1 test suite. How weird...
kennyluck: sounds like a bug in the grammar
This has been raised multiple times throughout the history of www-style, but I guess there was never a clear resolution.
kennyluck: if the grammar is not {u}{r}{l}'(' ... ')' or something close to that
allowing @document-\url ... but not background:\url() seems really weird
now removing escapes from what should be literals...
I would support that, but it seems a little late
especially considering the current dynamics of the CSS WG
annevk, David is in favor of what you think I guess. I think TabAtkins is against. I am probably against.
In any case, I need to fix the grammar or the test suite.
s/I/We/
kennyluck: dbaron? pointer?
kennyluck: and why would anyone be against removing complexity? compat concerns?
annevk, https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=751805#c3
odinho: fwiw, the question in that Origin header bug is about the Origin header not being required by HTML
odinho: because HTTP is not required
odinho: so you could opt to not include the Origin header and it's not entirely clear to the submitter of the bug what the requirements with respect to CORS are then
kennyluck: No, \url() shouldn't be a <url>.  It's an unknown function.  You only get a <url> from URL tokens, or from the image() function.
TabAtkins: why url() not work like any other syntax construct in CSS?
would /\
either you handle escapes everywhere or you don't
Because how does "\url(foo bar ! /* baz */)" work?  It definitely *doesn't* act like "url(foo bar ! /* baz */)".
TabAtkins: http://software.hixie.ch/utilities/js/live-dom-viewer/saved/1516 opera and gecko apply it

annevk: If it's never sending CORS requests, then they will always fail I guess. So in No CORS-mode you'll always get taint, in the CORS modes you'll always fail. -- I find the question a bit strange.
so does IE, but IE is in general just broken concerning CSS escape sequences...
s/CORS requests/an Origin header/
odinho: HTML CORS requests are not dependent on supporting CORS or something
odinho: the dependency chain is somewhat weird
it'll be fixed once we have fetch v2
but we don't
TabAtkins: i don't follow what the problem is with "\url(foo bar ! /* baz */)"
zcorpan: If you're not invoking the special URL token parsing, it looks like FUNCTION IDENT IDENT DELIM COMMENT CLOSE-PAREN.
And you can lose data there unless you're preserving comments and exact whitespace.
Even worse is what happens if you don't close the paren.
close the comment, i mean.
Then you get different results no matter what, because the URL token doesn't recognize a comment inside of itself.
But a FUNCTION token would.
but url(foo bar ! /* baz */) isn't valid anyway, is it?
No, I believe that's valid.
and corresponds to the url "foo bar ! /* baz */".
Which isn't a valid url, obviously, but still.
Well, space isn't valid in unquoted url() for what it's worth.
url(foo bar ! /* baz) is invalid, but it's well-defined and guaranteed to end at the ) character.
browsers don't seem to think it's valid
Oh, right, sorry.
That's true.
Seriously, I don't buy any argument here. My patch which changes Gecko to match WebKit has only 10 lines. We just need to agree on something.
So url(foo/*baz*/).
Yeah, it's simple in any direction.
I mean, I suppose I could make the tokenizer look for escaped u, r, and l to invoke the url token parsing.  It just doesn't seem necessary.
but that's what happens everywhere else
Oh, and here's a more realistic example: url(http://example.com/*)
it would be highly inconsistent not to look for escapes
TabAtkins: in opera/gecko, url(image?/**/) and \url(image?/**/) both load the image, while url(image/**/) and \url(image/**/) both don't
This is an invalid url token that ends at the ).  It's an unclosed comment if it's a function.
(in live dom viewer)
what happens for url(x()x)
or url([)])
(whether or not it follows the generic error handling)
Let's see what url([)]) does...
TabAtkins: http://software.hixie.ch/utilities/js/live-dom-viewer/saved/1518 gets applied in opera/gecko, so they don't tokenize a comment there
TabAtkins: i think i'd go with majority and make the tokenizer look for escaped url :-)
Putting together a decently comprehensive suite real quick.

Anyway, we had http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/www-style/2007Dec/0215 from annevk, http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/www-style/2010Jul/0499 from Bjoern Hoehrmann, http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/www-style/2011Apr/0680 from fantasai all about this for whoever is interested...
haven't changed my mind on this in 4+ years it seems
Yeah, I'll do whatever's reasonable and common.  Just trying to figure out what it is, comprehensively.
I did my initial spec from testing in webkit only. ^_^
TabAtkins, well, what you do is matching CSS 2.1 no there is no blame for you.
s/no/so/
That's true too.  Doesn't excuse sticking with 2.1 if it's clear that reality diverges, though.
I don't think I ever got a reply to that email btw
The correct answer is "nobody should ever touch the parser itself ever again".
CSS WG violated W3C Process, news at eleven
oh, film at eleven, doh
TabAtkins, hmm, once you have a decently comprehensive suite, you can unprefix!
Ms2ger: FINALLY
"PREFIX ALL THE FEATURES"
All right, everyone non-webkit agrees.
Escaping the u,r, and l characters are kosher, and it still invokes the URL token parsing.
So I'll fix that in the spec.  Kenny, feel free to patch accordingly.
That still means that \url(attr(foo)) won't do what that thread wanted, because you get the URL token parsing.
But like I said, image() handles that fine, because it parses as a FUNCTION instead.
TabAtkins, which means I need to patch CSS2. (my patch changes Gecko to match WebKit)
Well, I'll patch CSS2.1.
Don't match Webkit.
patch webkit! :-P
Yes!
TabAtkins, please do. I already add my mail to the long list of mails about this I mentioned above.
TabAtkins, only if you have proposed text and a test case ;)
Does anyone have an opinion on whether \u+1234 should be accepted as UNICODE-RANGE or not?
Ms2ger: I'm writing up an email with proposed text now.
kennyluck: What's the support?
That's all I really care about.  ^_^
TabAtkins, does any browser support 'unicode-range' already? Otherwise it can't be tested...
Yeah, I think that's supported pretty widely in @font-face.
I know that at least *some* browsers support it.
does anyone *use* unicode-range?
Can't answer that. ^_^
it seemed like a misfeature last time i looked at the spec
Not my place to say, within the context of css3-syntax.
"The CSS code above worked for me in Chrome and Safari on Mac OS X 10.6. but didn’t work in Firefox or Opera. Nor did it work in IE9 on Windows7"
If that's true, I am pretty sure WebKit follows the CSS 2.1 grammar so there's no support.
But well, I don't know if people will think that's inconsistent.
kennyluck: You can just use the CSSOM to query the property on the font-face rule, and see if it's been dropped or not.
It would be pretty dumb if every single browser was opposite (in different ways) in whether they support escapes in URL and UNICODE-RANGE.
It would be appropriate for the web
Oh, heh, we took the escaped-url as editorial, and then just forgot to make the edit.
(It's not editorial, of course.  No idea why they thought that.)
Ah, yup, and the change was covered by uri-015; it's just that the spec doesn't match the test.
So, annevk, no W3C Process was violated.  Just forgetfulness.  ^_^
ah, so that's how not to violate the process!
1. Make promises to edit something.
3. Profit!
yeah, we'll put in longdesc. promise.

yeah, those annoying commenters ;)
abarth: what's the status of http://wiki.whatwg.org/wiki/Meta_referrer ?
Hixie: it's in WebKit (though only shipping in Chrome and we might turn it off for Safari) and Mozilla at least at one point allegedly said they'd implement
k, guess i'll wait a bit longer then
Hixie: I'm not keen on the existence of the "always" value
Hixie: do you have an opinion?
what's the use case for 'always;?
I do not know
trackback, according to the page
"A blog hosted over HTTPS might wish to link to a blog hosted over HTTP and receive trackback links"
i assume it means "send trackback links"
it is kinda sad that moving to https kills referer
the reason for it doing so is historical and weird, but it's created an expectation of referer privacy for at least some users
so for example some people promote using google https search to get better privacy on the search queries used to reach a site
yeah
use of the "origin" value does not seem to break that assumption, but "always" would
(not sure that actually works btw)
there may well be back channels for all I know
Google Analytics and Google Webmaster tools provide some info in how users get on your site, including search queries
and links on search redirects are often redirects
search results :)
I've heard rumors there is interest in using the "origin" meta referrer value for SSL search but I haven't heard of anyone wanting to use "always"
I think people at Opera might have had concerns about "always" too. Although it was very informal discussion, and "people at Opera" might have just been "me" or something
so I would guess search providers care about whatever perceived privacy is gained by not sending the referrer
but they care about origin so they can promote their existence?
apparently, yes
or at least, they'd like content providers to know what traffic is being sent by their search engine, even if they don't know the exact query in any given case
because other than that (or CORS usage which does not apply here) it seems like a waste of bandwidth
the desire to send origin-as-referrer seems reasonable to me, though I'm in no position to explain anyone's business case for it
I guess the query is less and less exposed anyway with the search as you type stuff
personally i'd be fine with not ever sending referer, if we send origin
origin is useful for security
my understanding is that "SEO" people want to know what keywords are used to get to their site
(origin can also be a security/privacy problem itself, of course)
(e.g. leaking intranet host names)
not sending Referer will likely break a number of sites unfortunately
jesus, the number of ways that the <object> element's algorithm can be invoked has become ludicrously long
that use it to determine whether or not to display an image and such

more or less
